*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, a court may modify an existing custody order upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances that affects the best interests of the child. See *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).

Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody standards and repeatedly cites G.L. c. 208, § 31, but it does not invoke or apply G.L. c. 208, § 28 or the specific standard for *modification* of an existing custody order. The case concerns an initial custody determination in the context of dissolving a California registered domestic partnership, not a postjudgment modification upon a material and substantial change in circumstances. Therefore, citing Hunter v. Rose for the § 28 modification standard is inaccurate.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Furthermore, the Children’s best interests require the avoidance of parental conflict and the creation of conditions that foster stability. See *Hodgman v. Hodgman*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 14 (2009); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly grounds its best-interests analysis in the importance of preserving stability and continuity in a child’s living arrangements and warns against unnecessary disruption. The court states that a satisfactory existing placement should ordinarily be maintained, that stability is of enormous benefit to a child, and that unnecessary tampering with the status quo risks harm—all of which align with the proposition that a child’s best interests require minimizing conflict and fostering stable conditions.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 208, § 28 at all; it concerns custody and removal under G.L. c. 208, §§ 30 and 31. While the court repeatedly emphasizes that the child’s best interests, including emotional well-being and stability, are paramount, it does so in the context of the removal statute and custody determinations, not modifications under § 28, nor does it state that the statute ‘explicitly requires’ prioritizing the child’s needs over parental convenience. Thus the case supports the general best‑interests/child‑focused principle, but not the specific statutory proposition tied to § 28.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘[a] minor child… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … [T]he best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern….”
